questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL : TOOLS IN DATA SCIENCE (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"  ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: What does a correlation coefficient close to +1 indicate?
question_texts: What does a correlation coefficient close to +1 indicate?

options.option_text: A weak negative relationship between variables
A strong positive relationship between variables
A strong negative relationship between variables

questions.question_text_1: How can emotions be effectively used in data storytelling?
question_texts: How can emotions be effectively used in data storytelling?

options.option_text: By overwhelming the audience with excessive data
By highlighting the impact of data insights on real people or situations
By avoiding any form of visualization

questions.question_text_1: Which tool is particularly useful for cleaning messy data and transforming it into a structured format?
question_texts: Which tool is particularly useful for cleaning messy data and transforming it into a structured format?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following practices is considered unethical when performing web scraping?
question_texts: Which of the following practices is considered unethical when performing web scraping?

options.option_text: Avoiding excessive requests that could overwhelm the server
Scraping personal data without the user’s consent
Citing the source of data in your analysis

question_texts: What is the primary goal of data storytelling?

options.option_text: To analyze raw data without any context
To present data insights in a way that is engaging and understandable

questions.question_text_1: What does the term "continuous deployment" refer to?
question_texts: What does the term "continuous deployment" refer to?

options.option_text: Automatically deploying updates to production as soon as they pass testing
Deploying the model only once after completion
Deploying models to multiple platforms simultaneously

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is an important security consideration during deployment?
question_texts: Which of the following is an important security consideration during deployment?

options.option_text: Minimizing the size of the deployment package

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is a key consideration when deploying a data science model?
question_texts: Which of the following is a key consideration when deploying a data science model?

options.option_text: The model's interpretability and scalability in a production environment

questions.question_text_1: Why is version control important in the deployment of data science models?
question_texts: Why is version control important in the deployment of data science models?

options.option_text: It ensures that only one version of the model exists
It tracks changes and allows rollback to previous versions if necessary
It reduces the need for documentation

questions.question_text_1: Which factor is most important when choosing a deployment environment?
question_texts: Which factor is most important when choosing a deployment environment?

options.option_text: The visual appearance of the platform
The ease of integration with existing systems and scalability
The programming language used in the model
The geographical location of the user

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is an example of a data transformation process?
question_texts: Which of the following is an example of a data transformation process?

options.option_text: Changing a categorical variable into numeric values

questions.question_text_1: What is the purpose of the conclusion in a data story?
question_texts: What is the purpose of the conclusion in a data story?

options.option_text: To summarize the key findings and suggest actions or further considerations
To present the raw data in its entirety
To discuss the data collection process in detail

It allows for immediate model building

It allows the audience to understand the data in isolation
It helps the audience grasp the relevance and implications of the data

options.option_text: Their inability to perform complex calculations
Their potential to spread misinformation if not used carefully

question_texts: What is the purpose of data profiling in data preparation?

options.option_text: To assess the quality and structure of data

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following best describes an ordinal value?
question_texts: Which of the following best describes an ordinal value?

options.option_text: Data that is categorized without a specific order
Data that represents a specific order or ranking
Data measured on a scale with equal intervals
Data that can take on any value within a range

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true about Heroku?
question_texts: Which of the following is true about Heroku?

options.option_text: It is a data visualization tool
It is a cloud platform that allows easy deployment of web applications
It is used for creating machine learning models
It is a version control system

questions.question_text_1: What is a primary characteristic of large language models (LLMs)?
question_texts: What is a primary characteristic of large language models (LLMs)?

options.option_text: They are designed to handle small datasets efficiently
They are based on rule-based systems
They are trained on vast amounts of text data to generate human-like text
They are only used for numerical data analysis

questions.question_text_1: Why is data normalization important in the data preparation process?
question_texts: Why is data normalization important in the data preparation process?

options.option_text: To simplify the data collection process
To ensure that all data follows the same distribution
To remove outliers from the dataset
To scale data to a common range for better comparison

question_texts: Which of the following best describes linear regression?

options.option_text: A method to classify data into categories
A technique to find the relationship between a dependent variable and one ormore independent variables
A process of clustering similar data points
A way to visualize data trends over time

question_texts: What is the primary goal of deploying a data science model or application?

options.option_text: To make the model accessible to end-users for real-world application

questions.question_text_1: What is a significant requirement for training large language models effectively?
question_texts: What is a significant requirement for training large language models effectively?

options.option_text: High-quality labeled datasets of moderate size
Large amounts of unstructured text data and powerful computationalresources

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary objective of data analysis?
question_texts: What is the primary objective of data analysis?

options.option_text: To collect as much data as possible
To transform data into a usable format
To extract meaningful insights and patterns from data

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary goal of data visualization?
question_texts: What is the primary goal of data visualization?

options.option_text: To collect data from different sources
To present data in a way that makes patterns and insights easier tounderstand

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and tools** for the **"Tools in Data Science"** exam, along with **key equations** (where applicable) and **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts Summary**
#### **1. Data Storytelling & Visualization**
- **Goal**: Present data insights in an **engaging, understandable** way (Q7, Q20, Q24, Q38).
- **Key Elements**:
  - **Data analysis** + **visualizations** + **narrative** (Q20).
  - **Context**: Helps audience grasp relevance/implications (Q24).
  - **Emotions**: Highlight impact on real people/situations (Q3).
  - **Conclusion**: Summarize findings + suggest actions (Q15).
- **Tools**:
  - **Excel**: Forecast Sheet (trend analysis, Q17), Linked Text Boxes (dynamic narratives, Q32), Box Plots (outliers, Q33).
  - **Tableau**: Visualization (not explicitly tested but implied).
- **Visualization Types**:
  - **Bar charts**: Categorical data (Q22).
  - **Scatter plots/Line charts**: Continuous data/relationships (Q22).
  - **GIS**: Spatial data analysis (Q16).

#### **2. Data Cleaning & Preparation**
- **Tools**:
  - **OpenRefine**: Clean messy data (Q4).
  - **Power Query**: Scrape data from Excel (Q8).
  - **Excel**: PivotTables, Conditional Formatting (Q32).
- **Tasks**:
  - Remove duplicates, handle missing values, normalize data (Q23, Q30).
  - **Data profiling**: Assess quality/structure (Q26).
  - **Transformation**: Convert categorical → numeric (Q14).
- **Ethics**:
  - Avoid scraping **personal data without consent** (Q5).
  - Respect `robots.txt` (Q5).

#### **3. Web Scraping & APIs**
- **Formats**: JSON (common for scraping, Q21).
- **Tools**:
  - **Beautiful Soup/Selenium/Scrapy**: Web scraping (Q8).
  - **APIs**:
    - **Nominatim (OpenStreetMap)**: Geolocation from addresses (Q6).
    - **Twitter/Spotify/OpenWeatherMap**: Domain-specific data (Q6).
- **Ethical Scraping**:
  - Avoid overwhelming servers (Q5).
  - Cite sources (Q5).

#### **4. Data Analysis & Modeling**
- **Objective**: Extract **meaningful insights/patterns** (Q37).
- **Techniques**:
  - **Linear Regression**: Relationship between dependent-independent variables (Q31).
    - **Equation**:
      \( y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n + \epsilon \)
      (where \( y \) = dependent variable, \( \beta \) = coefficients, \( x \) = predictors, \( \epsilon \) = error).
  - **Time Series Forecasting**: ARIMA (Q34).
    - **ARIMA Equation**:
      \( y_t = c + \phi_1 y_{t-1} + ... + \phi_p y_{t-p} + \theta_1 \epsilon_{t-1} + ... + \theta_q \epsilon_{t-q} + \epsilon_t \)
      (where \( \phi \) = AR terms, \( \theta \) = MA terms, \( d \) = differencing order).
  - **Correlation Coefficient** (\( r \)):
    - **+1**: Strong positive relationship (Q2).
    - **-1**: Strong negative relationship.
    - **0**: No relationship.
    - **Equation**:
      \( r = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2 \sum (y_i - \bar{y})^2}} \)

#### **5. Deployment & Version Control**
- **Goal**: Make models **accessible to end-users** (Q35).
- **Key Considerations**:
  - **Scalability** + **interpretability** in production (Q11).
  - **Security**: Authentication/access controls (Q10).
  - **Deployment Environments**:
    - **Heroku**: Cloud platform for web apps (Q28).
    - **Continuous Deployment**: Auto-deploy updates post-testing (Q9).
- **Version Control** (e.g., Git):
  - Track changes, enable rollback (Q12).

#### **6. Large Language Models (LLMs)**
- **Characteristics**:
  - Trained on **vast text data** to generate human-like text (Q29).
  - Require **large unstructured datasets + computational power** (Q36).
- **Applications**:
  - **Text extraction**: Entity recognition (e.g., names in legal docs, Q19).
  - **Ethical Concerns**: Misinformation risk (Q25).
- **Limitations**: Not rule-based; rely on data patterns (Q29).

#### **7. Geospatial & Network Analysis**
- **GIS**: Analyze/visualize **spatial data** (Q16).
- **Geospatial Formats**: Shapefile (.shp) (Q39).
- **Network Analysis**:
  - **Degree Centrality**: Most "connected" node (Q40).

#### **8. Excel-Specific Tools**
| **Tool**          | **Purpose**                                  | **Question** |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------------|--------------|
| Forecast Sheet    | Predict trends from historical data        | Q17          |
| PivotTables       | Summarize/analyze data                     | Q32          |
| Conditional Formatting | Highlight patterns                     | Q32          |
| Box Plot          | Identify outliers                          | Q33          |
| Solver            | Optimization problems                      | Q17          |
| Linked Text Boxes | Dynamic narratives linked to data         | Q32          |

---

### **Key Equations**
1. **Linear Regression**:
   \( y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + ... + \beta_n x_n + \epsilon \)

2. **Correlation Coefficient (Pearson’s r)**:
   \( r = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2 \sum (y_i - \bar{y})^2}} \)

3. **ARIMA Model**:
   \( y_t = c + \sum_{i=1}^p \phi_i y_{t-i} + \sum_{j=1}^q \theta_j \epsilon_{t-j} + \epsilon_t \)

4. **Normalization (Min-Max)**:
   \( x_{\text{norm}} = \frac{x - x_{\text{min}}}{x_{\text{max}} - x_{\text{min}}} \)

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Data Science Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Data Collection] --> B[Data Cleaning]
    B --> C[Data Exploration]
    C --> D[Data Analysis]
    D --> E[Modeling]
    E --> F[Deployment]
    F --> G[Monitoring]
    B -->|Tools| H[OpenRefine]
    B -->|Tools| I[Power Query]
    D -->|Techniques| J[Linear Regression]
    D -->|Techniques| K[ARIMA]
    F -->|Platforms| L[Heroku]
    F -->|Practices| M[Version Control]
```

#### **2. Data Storytelling Components**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Data Storytelling] --> B[Narrative]
    A --> C[Visualizations]
    A --> D[Data Analysis]
    C --> E[Bar Charts]
    C --> F[Scatter Plots]
    C --> G[GIS Maps]
    D --> H[Correlation]
    D --> I[Trends]
    B --> J[Context]
    B --> K[Conclusion]
```

#### **3. Web Scraping & APIs**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Web Scraping] --> B[Tools]
    A --> C[Ethics]
    B --> D[Beautiful Soup]
    B --> E[Selenium]
    B --> F[Scrapy]
    C --> G[Respect robots.txt]
    C --> H[Avoid Personal Data]
    A -->|Output| I[JSON]
    A -->|Use Case| J[Text Extraction]
    J --> K[Entity Recognition]
```

#### **4. Deployment Pipeline**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Model Development] --> B[Testing]
    B --> C[Version Control]
    C --> D[Deployment]
    D --> E[Heroku]
    D --> F[Continuous Deployment]
    D --> G[Security]
    G --> H[Authentication]
    G --> I[Access Controls]
```

#### **5. Large Language Models (LLMs)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Large Language Models] --> B[Training Data]
    B --> C[Unstructured Text]
    B --> D[Computational Power]
    A --> E[Applications]
    E --> F[Text Extraction]
    E --> G[Summarization]
    A --> H[Ethical Concerns]
    H --> I[Misinformation]
    H --> J[Bias]
```
